conclusion: The image shows a green cloth as the background.
There are five blocks on the cloth: one green block (leftmost), two orange blocks stacked together (center-left), one blue block (center-right), two yellow blocks stacked together (rightmost).
An orange sphere labeled 'A' is shown falling freely from above towards the right.
The sphere is likely to impact the blocks on its path.
The sphere 'A' appears to be moving in such a way that it would first hit the nearest object along its trajectory, which seems to be the left edge of the yellow block on the right.
Upon impact, this block (the yellow one) may potentially deflect or rotate due to the force transfer from the sphere 'A'.
If the sphere 'A' impacts the left edge of the yellow block, the deflection effect could cause the entire block to move slightly but not necessarily fall over.
The block might shift slightly or possibly even rotate, depending on the force applied by the sphere and the block's resistance.

Assuming no significant deflection occurs beyond the initial impact, the orange sphere 'A' should come to rest near the edge of the yellow block since that seems to be the most stable contact point without further deflection.
The orange sphere 'A' will likely collide with the left edge of the yellow block.

The orange sphere 'A' will land near the edge of the yellow block, potentially causing slight movement or rotation of the yellow block, but it won't fall over significantly if the impact is not too strong.
